_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?
body:
Nice to see you! First we need to tackle the big question: Do I have what it takes to start a business? 


Let's start by getting one thing clear. Nobody can say for sure if your idea can become a successful business. If you want to find out, you have to try.


But there are ways to better predict your chances. Below you can out how to ask and answer the three big questions about any business idea: why this idea? why me? and why now?
title: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?

_items.title: Desirability
_items.body: Your idea needs to solve a clear need that people have. Your first reality check is to find out whether people actually face the problem you are aiming to solve.

You need to have the confidence that you can deliver, or will be able to, on the solution you imagine. Your second reality check is to consider if you will be able to solve the problem people are facing.
_items.title: Feasability
Viability
_items.body: You need to make sure the cost of solving people's problem is less than they are willing to pay. Your final reality check is to consider whether you can cover the costs of solving the problem from what you expect to be paid.

displayTitle: Giving your idea a reality check
body:
As the venture capitalist Vinod Khosla said: 'Nobody will pay you for solving a non-problem.'


So can you decide if you idea is a problem worth solving? There are three main reality checks your idea needs to pass. Click on the boxes below to find out more.
title: Giving your idea a reality check

body: Even if your idea passes the reality check, it’s likely someone else had a similar thought. These are potential competitors. For any business to be successful, it needs to do something different to its competitors. That difference is why customers will choose you over them. To decide what to do differently, you will need a value proposition. A valuae proposition is your solution to your customer's problem. A good one will say how you solve the probelm and why your solution is the best available.
displayTitle: Making sure your idea is unique
instruction: Click the video on the right to learn more...
title: Making sure your idea is unique

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

_items.body:
Entrepreneurs see problems as opportunities. They also don't like leaving these opportunities for someone else to pursue.


Do you look at problems in your life and instantly think about how to solve them?
_items.title: Seeking opportunity

_items.body:
Entrepreneurs take a risk on a future business rather than looking for a safe job today.


Are you a 'poker player' who is willing to take measured risks to secure future returns?
_items.title: Taking risks before security
Tolerating Failure
_items.body:
Entrepreneurs fail often but never let that failure deter them.


Do you have the desire to experiment, fail and keep going?

Entrepreneurs often have to do without the right talent and improvise solutions with what they have.


Do you have the ability to get what you need from your friends and network?
_items.title: Creatively leveraging resources

_items.body:
Entrepreneurs regularly have to deal with doubt and uncertainty over their future.


Do you have the passion and persistence to learn from the inevitable set-backs and drive ideas into action?
_items.title: Tenacity to overcome obstacles and push an idea to implementation

displayTitle: Assessing if this business is a good fit for you
body:
You may have a great idea, but are you the person who should be making it into a business? After all being an entrepreneur isn’t for everyone. So how can you decide if this idea is a good match for you?


There are some key traits many startup founders share. Scroll through them below and think about how many you have.
title: Assessing if this business is a good fit for you

_items.body:
Victor Hugo said ‘Nothing is as powerful as an idea whose time has come’. So how can you figure out if this is the right time for your business?


Successful businesses can spot can spot when a change creates new opportunities. Nokia was originally a paper mill, Sony sold radios and Mitel was a maker of lawnmowers. All of them saw a change and identified an opportunity to succeed.


For your idea to be successful, you will need to think carefully about this. What has changed in the world that will influence people to buy from you? It might be that you offer a brand new technology, solve a new problem or make something more affordable and practical.


Whatever the change, you need to be clear on how the world today will contribute to making your business a success. Having a clear answer to this question will boost your odds of success.

displayTitle: Getting the timings right
title: Getting the timings right

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Desirability (does anyone need it?), Feasibility (can we do it?) and Viability (do we have the resources to make it work?) are the essential reality checks for any new idea.

_feedback.correct:
That’s Right!


Desirability (does anyone need it?), Feasibility (can we do it?) and Viability (do we have the resources to make it work?) are the essential reality checks for any new idea.

displayTitle: Taking a reality check
body: Can you find all the criteria that you would use to give your new business idea a reality check?
instruction: Select all the options that match then hit submit!
title: Taking a reality check

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


A value proposition is your solution to a customer’s problem. There are lots of other ways of putting this but thinking about a solution and a problem is an easy way to remember!

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!


A value proposition is your solution to a customer’s problem.

displayTitle: Nailing that value proposition
body: Earlier we learned how a value proposition helps you nail down your idea. But how would you define the idea if someone asked you?
instruction: Fill in the blanks in the sentence below then hit submit
title: Nailing that value proposition

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Have another go!
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Hit 'show answer' to check out our definitions.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Have another go!

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


You know those skills like the back of your hand!

_dropZones.text: You look at problems and see the solutions
You are willing to take a risk for a future return
You can improvise solutions where none exist
You move on fast from your mistakes

displayTitle: Taking a look in the mirror
body: While every entrepreneur is different, many share a particular set of traits. Can you match up the names of the trait to their descriptions?
instruction: Drag the titles onto the images then hit select
title: Taking a look in the mirror

body:
Well done! you've finished your first module.

Everything we've learnt above is important when considering if your idea has what it takes to become a business. We recommend taking some time to consider why this idea? why me? why now? and what next? They will give you the foundation on which your business is built.


So what happens once you have answers you need? The next thing you need is to structure your answers into something you can use. In the next module we will give you the skills to turn your idea into a business model you can share with others.
displayTitle: You have what it takes!
title: You have what it takes!

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

body: Even if your idea passes the reality check, it’s likely someone else had a similar thought. These are potential competitors. For any business to be successful, it needs to do something different to its competitors. That difference is why customers will choose you over them. To decide what to do differently, you will need a value proposition. A valuae proposition is your solution to your customer's problem. A good one will say how you solve the probelm and why your solution is the best available.
displayTitle: Making sure your idea is unique
instruction: Click the video on the right to learn more...
title: Making sure your idea is unique

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: Assessing if this business is a good fit for you
body:
You may have a great idea, but are you the person who should be making it into a business? After all being an entrepreneur isn’t for everyone. So how can you decide if this idea is a good match for you?


There are some key traits many startup founders share. Scroll through them below and think about how many you have.

_items.title: Seeking opportunity
_items.body:
Entrepreneurs see problems as opportunities. They also don't like leaving these opportunities for someone else to pursue.


Do you look at problems in your life and instantly think about how to solve them?

_items.title: Taking risks before security
_items.body:
Entrepreneurs take a risk on a future business rather than looking for a safe job today.


Are you a 'poker player' who is willing to take measured risks to secure future returns?

Entrepreneurs fail often but never let that failure deter them.


Do you have the desire to experiment, fail and keep going?
_items.title: Tolerating Failure
Creatively leveraging resources
_items.body:
Entrepreneurs often have to do without the right talent and improvise solutions with what they have.


Do you have the ability to get what you need from your friends and network?

_items.title: Tenacity to overcome obstacles and push an idea to implementation
_items.body:
Entrepreneurs regularly have to deal with doubt and uncertainty over their future.


Do you have the passion and persistence to learn from the inevitable set-backs and drive ideas into action?

title: Assessing if this business is a good fit for you

displayTitle: Getting the timings right

_items.body:
Victor Hugo said ‘Nothing is as powerful as an idea whose time has come’. So how can you figure out if this is the right time for your business?


Successful businesses can spot can spot when a change creates new opportunities. Nokia was originally a paper mill, Sony sold radios and Mitel was a maker of lawnmowers. All of them saw a change and identified an opportunity to succeed.


For your idea to be successful, you will need to think carefully about this. What has changed in the world that will influence people to buy from you? It might be that you offer a brand new technology, solve a new problem or make something more affordable and practical.


Whatever the change, you need to be clear on how the world today will contribute to making your business a success. Having a clear answer to this question will boost your odds of success.

title: Getting the timings right

displayTitle: Taking a reality check
body: Can you find all the criteria that you would use to give your new business idea a reality check?
instruction: Select all the options that match then hit submit!

_feedback.correct:
That’s Right!


Desirability (does anyone need it?), Feasibility (can we do it?) and Viability (do we have the resources to make it work?) are the essential reality checks for any new idea.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Desirability (does anyone need it?), Feasibility (can we do it?) and Viability (do we have the resources to make it work?) are the essential reality checks for any new idea.

title: Taking a reality check

displayTitle: Nailing that value proposition
body: Earlier we learned how a value proposition helps you nail down your idea. But how would you define the idea if someone asked you?
instruction: Fill in the blanks in the sentence below then hit submit

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!


A value proposition is your solution to a customer’s problem.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


A value proposition is your solution to a customer’s problem. There are lots of other ways of putting this but thinking about a solution and a problem is an easy way to remember!

title: Nailing that value proposition

displayTitle: Taking a look in the mirror
body: While every entrepreneur is different, many share a particular set of traits. Can you match up the names of the trait to their descriptions?
instruction: Drag the titles onto the images then hit select

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


You know those skills like the back of your hand!

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Have another go!

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Have another go!
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Hit 'show answer' to check out our definitions.

_dropZones.text: You look at problems and see the solutions
You are willing to take a risk for a future return
You can improvise solutions where none exist
You move on fast from your mistakes

title: Taking a look in the mirror

body:
Well done! you've finished your first module.

Everything we've learnt above is important when considering if your idea has what it takes to become a business. We recommend taking some time to consider why this idea? why me? why now? and what next? They will give you the foundation on which your business is built.


So what happens once you have answers you need? The next thing you need is to structure your answers into something you can use. In the next module we will give you the skills to turn your idea into a business model you can share with others.
displayTitle: You have what it takes!
title: You have what it takes!

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?
body:
Nice to see you! First we need to tackle the big question: Do I have what it takes to start a business? 


Let's start by getting one thing clear. Nobody can say for sure if your idea can become a successful business. If you want to find out, you have to try.


But there are ways to better predict your chances. Below you can out how to ask and answer the three big questions about any business idea: why this idea? why me? and why now?
title: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?

displayTitle: Giving your idea a reality check
body:
As the venture capitalist Vinod Khosla said: 'Nobody will pay you for solving a non-problem.'


So can you decide if you idea is a problem worth solving? There are three main reality checks your idea needs to pass. Click on the boxes below to find out more.

_items.body: Your idea needs to solve a clear need that people have. Your first reality check is to find out whether people actually face the problem you are aiming to solve.
_items.title: Desirability
Feasability
_items.body: You need to have the confidence that you can deliver, or will be able to, on the solution you imagine. Your second reality check is to consider if you will be able to solve the problem people are facing.

You need to make sure the cost of solving people's problem is less than they are willing to pay. Your final reality check is to consider whether you can cover the costs of solving the problem from what you expect to be paid.
_items.title: Viability

title: Giving your idea a reality check

body: Even if your idea passes the reality check, it’s likely someone else had a similar thought. These are potential competitors. For any business to be successful, it needs to do something different to its competitors. That difference is why customers will choose you over them. To decide what to do differently, you will need a value proposition. A valuae proposition is your solution to your customer's problem. A good one will say how you solve the probelm and why your solution is the best available.
